mistake: Using 'any' when referring to a specific item
original_text: I didn't watch any movie, bro.
corrected_text: I didn't watch a movie, bro.

mistake: Using 'any' when referring to a specific item
original_text: He didn't find any solution.
corrected_text: He didn't find a solution.

mistake: Using 'any' when referring to a specific item
original_text: She couldn't see any star.
corrected_text: She couldn't see a star.

mistake: Using 'any' when referring to a specific item
original_text: I haven't watched any TV show.
corrected_text: I haven't watched a TV show.

mistake: Using 'any' when referring to a specific item
original_text: We didn't make any decision.
corrected_text: We didn't make a decision.

mistake: Using 'any' when referring to a specific item
original_text: They didn't attend any meeting.
corrected_text: They didn't attend a meeting.

mistake: Mismatch between subject and verb number
original_text: The group of students are here.
corrected_text: The group of students is here.

mistake: Mismatch between subject and verb number
original_text: My cat and dog runs every morning.
corrected_text: My cat and dog run every morning.

mistake: Mismatch between subject and verb number
original_text: Each of the answers were correct.
corrected_text: Each of the answers was correct.

mistake: Mismatch between subject and verb number
original_text: The list of items were on the table.
corrected_text: The list of items was on the table.

mistake: Mismatch between subject and verb number
original_text: Neither of the books have been read.
corrected_text: Neither of the books has been read.

mistake: Incorrect use of prepositions in context
original_text: She is married with a doctor.
corrected_text: She is married to a doctor.

mistake: Incorrect use of prepositions in context
original_text: We are interested for the project.
corrected_text: We are interested in the project.

mistake: Incorrect use of prepositions in context
original_text: He is good in math.
corrected_text: He is good at math.

mistake: Incorrect use of prepositions in context
original_text: She relies in her friends.
corrected_text: She relies on her friends.

mistake: Incorrect use of prepositions in context
original_text: They are dependent from external help.
corrected_text: They are dependent on external help.

mistake: Using wrong verb form in past participle
original_text: She has went to the store.
corrected_text: She has gone to the store.

mistake: Using wrong verb form in past participle
original_text: He had ate earlier.
corrected_text: He had eaten earlier.

mistake: Using wrong verb form in simple past
original_text: They seen the movie last week.
corrected_text: They saw the movie last week.

mistake: Using wrong verb form in simple past
original_text: We choose the best option yesterday.
corrected_text: We chose the best option yesterday.

mistake: Using wrong verb form in past participle
original_text: You should have went there.
corrected_text: You should have gone there.
